text: Hey, I'd certainly check out the charm offensive for something a little different. A few quirky examples for sure in there but I love the mantra and style <https://www.charm-offensive.co.uk/>. You can get a few free examples I think also.

attachments.title: Unorthodox and daring sales & marketing
attachments.text: I was desperate for sales. I got blind drunk and wrote the most absurd cold email I could muster. To my amazement, it worked. I booked meetings with RedBull, Hewlett Packard, Symantec and countless other global brands.
attachments.fallback: Charm Offensive: Unorthodox and daring sales & marketing

text: Anyone here able to provide a :+1: or :-1: for using SEMrush as part of their content marketing stack? They seem to have really upped their game adding in competitor research and content generation tools but always best to hear from those "in the trenches" who has used it first hand?

elements.text: Anyone here able to provide a
or

for using SEMrush as part of their content marketing stack? They seem to have really upped their game adding in competitor research and content generation tools but always best to hear from those "in the trenches" who has used it first hand?

text:
It has some useful features, so it’s part my stack. Other tools (besides GA/GSC):
• Ahrefs (competitor research re: keywords and backlinks)
• ContentKing (monitoring for changes and issues)
• <https://alsoasked.com/> (seeing People Also Asked questions)

elements.text: It has some useful features, so it’s part my stack. Other tools (besides GA/GSC):
Ahrefs (competitor research re: keywords and backlinks)
ContentKing (monitoring for changes and issues)
(seeing People Also Asked questions)

text: Having more data is always better, so e.g. when doing keyword research you can use both SEMrush and Ahrefs data and calculate an average.

elements.text: Having more data is always better, so e.g. when doing keyword research you can use both SEMrush and Ahrefs data and calculate an average.

text:
Yes! We saw a lot of engagement and our sales team saw more personalized responses to their emails when they sent it out than any other campaign we've done so far. I think we had just a couple of "conversions" of booking AE appts. We also spun it up really quickly. Quicker than I would have wanted haha. But it was our first attempt at a quiz for demand gen with this team, and in that way, I think it was a success. Here's the link:
<https://www.jobvite.com/recruiter-animal-squad-quiz/>

text: Gotcha!  The problem is that if she moves the needle in terms of putting out more content or pages (best in the long run), that CTR will drop for a bit until those pages start to rank well. My fear would be it'd encourage near-term hedging that results in long-term losses. :man-shrugging:

text: 0verall :+1: With these seo tools a lot of keyword counts are directional. I can say that SEMRush has some serious discrepancy, so add some salt if you’re doing keyword research. To me where it shines is competitor research. Keyword Gap Tool. Put in your site and your competitors, see where they have rankings that you don’t. You can filter for questions too, add “what” keyword filter to get TOF/MOF/BOF question ideas for content. There’s a few other things they do well. Some things they are just okay at. I also use Keywords Everywhere extension (paid but super cheap). GSC, GA (engagement metrics).

elements.text: 0verall

With these seo tools a lot of keyword counts are directional. I can say that SEMRush has some serious discrepancy, so add some salt if you’re doing keyword research. To me where it shines is competitor research. Keyword Gap Tool. Put in your site and your competitors, see where they have rankings that you don’t. You can filter for questions too, add “what” keyword filter to get TOF/MOF/BOF question ideas for content. There’s a few other things they do well. Some things they are just okay at. I also use Keywords Everywhere extension (paid but super cheap). GSC, GA (engagement metrics).

text:
Hey All -

Would love your feedback/thoughts!

We currently send out 90% of our email comms from SendGrid, mainly because it connects product emails (I.e. forgot password, etc) as well, so when we go through unsubscribing people, it’s easy to have one central place.

We also use Intercom for email onboarding.

However, sending newsletters through this feels like a complete waste because the only analytics I’m able to get are: how many people opened, clicked a link, unsubscribed, etc. Also can’t a/b test.

My issue is that, for our blog newsletters and feature digests, we can’t properly track or see within sendgrid who’s clicking on which links (so we deliver more of that content), it’s all static lists, and we don’t get proper knowledge into what’s working vs not.

While I know I can do a lot of this through UTMS (which I still add to links) I think it ends up being a lot more work than seeing a snapshot from that specific email. It also doesn’t allow us to see what features people are most interested in (because all of the links lead to the login/sign up page).

*So my question is…*
1. What’s your email tech stack? Including product, transactional and marketing.
2. Is it okay that marketing emails live in a separate world to product-specific ones (transnational and onboarding).
3. What would you do in my position?

elements.text:
Hey All -

Would love your feedback/thoughts!

We currently send out 90% of our email comms from SendGrid, mainly because it connects product emails (I.e. forgot password, etc) as well, so when we go through unsubscribing people, it’s easy to have one central place.

We also use Intercom for email onboarding.

However, sending newsletters through this feels like a complete waste because the only analytics I’m able to get are: how many people opened, clicked a link, unsubscribed, etc. Also can’t a/b test.

My issue is that, for our blog newsletters and feature digests, we can’t properly track or see within sendgrid who’s clicking on which links (so we deliver more of that content), it’s all static lists, and we don’t get proper knowledge into what’s working vs not.

While I know I can do a lot of this through UTMS (which I still add to links) I think it ends up being a lot more work than seeing a snapshot from that specific email. It also doesn’t allow us to see what features people are most interested in (because all of the links lead to the login/sign up page).
So my question is…
What’s your email tech stack? Including product, transactional and marketing.
Is it okay that marketing emails live in a separate world to product-specific ones (transnational and onboarding).
What would you do in my position?

text:
We use our own product (not sure helpful there I know), to create channels with RSS feeds much like Sean mentioned. It can be set up to ping Slack, email, a Chrome extension, or in various CRM’s to keep everyone engaged where they are, unless they want to be in the product looking for/searching content feeds.

Also, we have placed some more routine, high value content in our HubSpot CRM (under Sales > Documents) in which they can quickly attach the document via email or create a link to the document to send to people the are talking with.

elements.text:
We use our own product (not sure helpful there I know), to create channels with RSS feeds much like Sean mentioned. It can be set up to ping Slack, email, a Chrome extension, or in various CRM’s to keep everyone engaged where they are, unless they want to be in the product looking for/searching content feeds.

Also, we have placed some more routine, high value content in our HubSpot CRM (under Sales > Documents) in which they can quickly attach the document via email or create a link to the document to send to people the are talking with.

text:
Email sends are always a predicament. We send our product stuff through SendGrid, keep our marketing emails in Marketo, CS sends emails via ChurnZero, and then we have SalesLoft/Salesvue for reps to send cadence emails so things are a bit all over the place.

What I like about keeping marketing separate from other comms is someone may unsub from us, but still want product alerts and vice versa. However this is linked to Salesloft/Salesvue so the person won't continue to receive promotional/sales emails.

Our marketing list isn't super segmented so someone can't opt out of the newsletter but still get product release news (which we send via Marketo with support from CS & Sales activity), it's all or nothing on that front.

If you're looking to build an optimized email program I'd invest in a tool that gives you what you need without a ton of manual effort on the backend.

elements.text:
Email sends are always a predicament. We send our product stuff through SendGrid, keep our marketing emails in Marketo, CS sends emails via ChurnZero, and then we have SalesLoft/Salesvue for reps to send cadence emails so things are a bit all over the place.

What I like about keeping marketing separate from other comms is someone may unsub from us, but still want product alerts and vice versa. However this is linked to Salesloft/Salesvue so the person won't continue to receive promotional/sales emails.

Our marketing list isn't super segmented so someone can't opt out of the newsletter but still get product release news (which we send via Marketo with support from CS & Sales activity), it's all or nothing on that front.

If you're looking to build an optimized email program I'd invest in a tool that gives you what you need without a ton of manual effort on the backend.

Our list segmentation is definitely very, very bad right now and almost non-existent. :woman-facepalming::skin-tone-2: But, as a team of one… It’s not something that’s affected us negatively (but can definitely do better), so more of a matter of what our priorities are.

text:
Hi <@U010JU2GTND>, I've recently moved jobs, so I no longer use SG, but I wrestled with that product for years. At the time, I felt like it wasn't really built for marketing at all (like you, we used it because the devs liked it for pushing transactional emails). However, it did seem like they were pushing out more marketing-friendly features just when I stopped using it, perhaps due to being acquired by Twilio.

FWIW, there's a roadmap here, and it seems like better analytics / tracking is the next cab off the rank: <https://sendgrid.com/docs/ui/sending-email/coming-soon-to-new-marketing-campaigns/>

So it might depend how patient you are! Or how much you trust product roadmaps :grimacing:

Also, IIRC, you can A/B test a single send newsletter with Sendgrid now. Perhaps it's newish or restricted to certain plans?: <https://sendgrid.com/docs/ui/sending-email/a-b-testing/>

elements.text: of course! DM away!

text: For SaaS, I’ve used Drip w/ GoSquared, which covers both transactional, marketing, and onboarding (they also separate transactional from marketing internally, so people can be unsub-ed from marketing but still receive transactional emails). I kinda like having everything in one place, so I can make sure no messaging/emails are conflicting and that we’re not sending too much or too little. Having said that, I think it’s fine to separate transactional and onboarding from marketing if you really like your current stack and think segmentation will really push the needle for marketing/sales.

elements.text: For SaaS, I’ve used Drip w/ GoSquared, which covers both transactional, marketing, and onboarding (they also separate transactional from marketing internally, so people can be unsub-ed from marketing but still receive transactional emails).
